items.title: Alberta premier says loss of measles elimination status concerning, urges vigilance
items.summary_auto: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith says Canada recently losing its measles elimination status is concerning, but her government might not have many other options on the table to help get it back.

items.title: Trump cuts tariffs on beef, coffee and other foods, as U.S. inflation concerns mount
Iran’s 'water bankruptcy problem' is nothing new, says UN expert
items.summary_auto: The country of more than 90 million is facing an unprecedented water and energy crisis as reservoirs shrink to record lows, endangering drinking water and power supplies.

items.title: Residents of this Ontario neighbourhood were hit with $14K per household for work done a decade ago
Paulatuk, N.W.T., wants to fix drafty homes as part of its net-zero goal
items.summary_auto: The Paulatuk Energy Working Group has a goal of becoming carbon neutral. But everyone – from residents to those leading the project – agree making sure homes don’t waste that energy is a critical part of the target.

items.title: Man found guilty of murder in stabbing death of Misha Pavelick at Sask. grad party in 2006
items.summary_auto: A man has been found guilty of second-degree murder in the death of Misha Pavelick, 19, who was fatally stabbed during a graduation party at a campground.

items.title: Spacecraft designed to study the effect of solar storms delayed by a solar storm
items.summary_auto: Bob’s Blog: NASA’s latest mission, designed to study the effects of the solar wind on the atmosphere of Mars, was ironically delayed on the launch pad due to a solar storm affecting conditions here on Earth.

items.title: What are the ultra-processed foods we eat and why does it matter to our health?
items.summary_auto: Almost half of what Canadians eat are ultra-processed foods that harm health and are under scrutiny for links to major heart diseases and cancer at the same time that consumption is going up.

items.title: Car crashes through entrance at Home Hardware in Saskatoon
items.summary_auto: Around 1:30 AM Friday, a car swerved off Central Avenue in the Sutherland neighbourhood and blew through the front entrance of a Home Hardware store. By 8:00 a.m., the owner had the place ready to open for business as usual.

items.title: Snowy CPL final featuring viral 'icicle kick' exceeds 1 billion views, league says
items.summary_auto: The snowy Canadian Premier League final, which featured a blizzard and an audacious bicycle kick, has generated over one billion views, according to a spokesperson from the league.

items.title: Winnipeg couple plead guilty to animal cruelty after killing cats, birds, axolotl for videos they sold
items.summary_auto: A Winnipeg couple have pleaded guilty to multiple counts of animal cruelty after being arrested last year for making videos of animals being tortured and killed and selling them on a messaging app — a venture that included more than 90 animals, ranging from kittens to birds to an axolotl.

items.title: Desperate parents needing baby formula turn to online strangers as Canadian prices nearly double since 2017
Interim parliamentary budget officer takes aim at Liberal accounting, but says budget sustainable
items.summary_auto: Days before MPs are set to cast their vote on the Liberal budget, interim Parliamentary Budget Officer Jason Jacques is calling the government’s accounting into question, suggesting there’s a less than 10 per cent chance it will stay within its deficit targets.

items.title: Bad Bunny cleans up at Latin Grammys, Ca7riel & Paco Amoroso and Karol G take home big awards
items.summary_auto: Bad Bunny won album of the year for Debí Tirar Más Fotos, a tour de force mixing styles from Afro-Caribbean to salsa that netted him 12 nominations. The artist, who'll take centre field at the Super Bowl in New Orleans in February, also won for best urban/urban fusion performance, reggaeton performance, urban music album and urban song.

items.title: Ariana Grande rushed by fan on Wicked: For Good carpet in Singapore — then Cynthia Erivo stepped in
items.summary_auto: Cynthia Erivo came to the rescue of The Wicked: For Good co-star Ariana Grande when a man rushed Grande, forcibly putting an arm around her, while on the yellow carpet for the Singapore premiere of the film, prompting security to take him away and a Singapore court to fine him $2,000.

items.title: Some Starbucks workers in the U.S. are on strike. Here's why
items.summary_auto: Unionized baristas from 65 Starbucks locations across the U.S. launched a strike on Thursday.

items.title: Fall drought could spell water troubles for central Alberta regions, expert says
items.summary_auto: Large swaths of Alberta are experiencing extreme drought conditions. Some farmers are thinking twice about the amount of water they use heading into the winter months.

items.title: Indigenous protesters block entrance to Brazil climate summit
items.summary_auto: Dozens of Indigenous protesters blocked the front of the COP30 summit venue in Belem, Brazil, on Friday morning, staging a sit-in that forced delegates to use a side entrance to resume their negotiations on tackling climate change.

items.title: Florida carries out record 16th execution of the year, for child murderer sentenced to death in 1980
items.summary_auto: A man convicted of the 1979 killing of a six-year-old girl who was abducted from her bedroom has been put to death in a record 16th execution in Florida this year.

items.title: Police say about 75 people commit an inordinate amount of crime in Calgary. Who are they?
items.summary_auto: Calgary police refer to them as 'high system users' — a relatively small number of individuals who have initiated 'hundreds of calls for service' for social disorder or crime. Here's how they break it down.

items.title: Nenshi’s NDP relaunch gets big outside help: NYC mayor's ad agency and Ottawa Liberals
items.summary_auto: Nearly a year and a half after Naheed Nenshi began serving as Alberta NDP leader, and about two years out from the next scheduled election, his party has determined it’s time to reintroduce him to Albertans this week.

items.title: 'I'm hoping for a miracle': Breslau, Ont., neighbours on hook for $14K per household for decade-old sewer work
items.summary_auto: People living in a Breslau, Ont., neighbourhood received letters this week saying they're expected to pay almost $14,000 per household for sewer and water work done in 2016. Some said they had no idea the bill was coming, while the Township of Woolwich says it should have had better communication with affected property owners.

items.title: 6 killed, dozens injured in Russian drone and missile attack on Kyiv overnight
items.summary_auto: Russia launched a heavy drone and missile attack on Ukraine early on Friday, killing six people in Kyiv and two more in the south in strikes on energy facilities, apartment buildings and infrastructure, Ukrainian officials said.

items.title: They’re at risk of dying from opioid overdose. The government cut funding that could help them
Gen Z diners snubbing the high cost of fast food. Can they be lured back?
items.summary_auto: Fast-food chains like Chipotle and McDonald’s are lowering their sales forecasts for next year and luring people in with value meals as they foresee a pullback in spending from low-income and younger diners.

items.title: 5-year-old Masa has been missing for more than a year. Hope arrives when a small, patent leather shoe is found
items.summary_auto: Mu’ayyad Ajjour and his neighbour Mohamed Zaida have searched every day among the ruins of a building, hoping to find the remains of five-year-old Masa, Ajjour's cousin, so they can give her a proper burial. Her body is one of thousands thought to be buried in the debris of the war in Gaza.

items.title: Health Canada ignored expert advice to expand access to safe drugs for opioid users, internal documents show
items.summary_auto: As deadly drug overdoses climbed across Canada, decision-makers faced political backlash for funding programs that gave drug users prescribed opioids and, against their own experts’ advice, scaled back their support of safe supply programs, an investigation by CBC’s the fifth estate has found.

items.title: Donald Trump’s 50-year mortgage plan is being panned. It also wouldn’t fly in Canada
items.summary_auto: Many industry observers have been cool to Donald Trump’s proposal to allow 50-year mortgages in the United States. And it’s very unlikely such an idea would gain traction anytime soon in Canada, where amortization periods have been shortened over the last two decades.

items.title: The fast-food industry is trying to lure in Gen Z diners. Is the meal deal helping?
items.summary_auto: Fast-food chains like Chipotle and McDonald’s are lowering their sales forecasts for next year and luring people in with value meals as they foresee a pullback in spending from low-income and younger diners.

items.title: You could get at least $50 from the bread price-fixing settlement. But the deadline is coming up
items.summary_auto: Your chance to get a piece of a $500-million class action settlement, following a years-long bread price fixing scheme will soon expire.

items.title: Doctors, pharmacists urging Ontarians to get flu shots as province sees rise in cases
items.summary_auto: As flu cases rise across the province and vaccine hesitancy persists, Ontario pharmacists and doctors are urging residents to get immunized.

items.title: Glen Powell's The Running Man seriously runs out of steam
items.summary_auto: Edgar Wright's The Running Man does boast impressive action sequences. But any cultural observation the 1980 Stephen King story once offered seems out of date now.
